description: First attested in 1561, borrowed from Latin relēgātus, the past participle of relēgō (“to dispatch, banish”).

verbs.description: relegate (third-person singular simple present relegates, present participle relegating, simple past and past participle relegated)

definitionGroups.group: Exile, banish, remove, or send away.

entries.meaning: (transitive, done to a person) Exile or banish to a particular place.
(reflexive, obsolete, rare) Remove (oneself) to a distance from something or somewhere.
(transitive, historical, Ancient Rome, done to a person) Banish from proximity to Rome for a set time; compare relegate.
(transitive, figuratively) Remove or send to a place far away.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, in extended use) Consign or assign.

entries.meaning: Consign (a person or thing) to a place, position, or role of obscurity, insignificance, oblivion, lower rank or (especially) inferiority.
examples: Her bright ideas were relegated to "tosh" by her manager.

entries.meaning: Assign (a thing) to an appropriate place or situation based on appraisal or classification.
(sports, chiefly soccer) Transfer (a sports team) to a lower-ranking league division.
examples: After finishing second-bottom in the table, United were relegated from the division.

entries.meaning: Refer (a point of contention) to an authority in deference to the judgment thereof.
Submit (something) to someone else for appropriate action thereby; compare delegate.
(now rare) Submit or refer (someone) to someone or something else for some reason or purpose.

description: First attested circa 1550: from the Classical Latin relēgātus (“banished person, exile”), the nominative singular masculine substantive form of relēgātus, the past participle of relēgō (“to dispatch, banish”).

entries.meaning: (history, obsolete) A person who has been banished from proximity to Rome for a set time, but without losing his civil rights.

description: First attested circa 1425: from the Classical Latin relēgātus, the perfect passive participle of relēgō (“I dispatch”, “I banish”).
